channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea Repeats Call for Talks
item.description: A senior North Korean diplomat said Wednesday that his country was willing to have “any kind of talks” to ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Egypt’s Government Broadens Its Accusations Against Islamists
item.description: The new military-led government accused Mohamed Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood of a campaign to incite violence before and after his ouster as president.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Newly-appointed prosecutor general Hisham Barakat, left, is sworn in in front of interim president, Adli Mansour, right, at the presidential palace in Cairo on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel Reopens Inquiry Into Activist’s Injury
item.description: The Israeli police on Wednesday agreed to re-investigate the 2009 injury of an American activist during a clash between Israeli security forces and protesters.
item.dc:creator: By MYRA NOVECK

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Interior Ministry Reopening in Libya
item.description: The Libyan government has taken back control of its Interior Ministry from an armed group that had besieged the building for a week, an official said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Hopes Rise for Appeal of Ex-Marine Held in Iran
item.description: Improvements in prison life for Amir Hekmati, incarcerated for nearly two years on spying accusations, strengthened his family’s hope that Iran’s judiciary would favorably review an appeal for his release.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Accident’s Toll Grows Further in Quebec
item.description: The police reported that the remains of 20 people had been found.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Taliban Spokesman Is Ousted for ‘Creating Mistrust’
item.description: Leaflets distributed this week in North Waziristan, the main hub of Taliban militancy in Pakistan, announced that the spokesman, Sajjid Mohmand, was being replaced.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Labels Leave a Bad Taste
item.description: Sales figures are not available to help determine the effectiveness of an Australian law requiring graphic images on cigarette packages. But some smokers swear there has been a change in the tobacco.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Health warnings on tobacco products in a store in Sydney. In addition to requiring graphic imagery on tobacco labels, Australia taxes tobacco heavily.

item.title: Some Trees Use Less Water Amid Rising Carbon Dioxide, Paper Says
item.description: New research suggests that trees in at least some parts of the world are having to pull less water out of the ground to achieve a given amount of growth.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: A device in Michigan monitored the exchange of gases between the forest and the atmosphere.

item.title: Tightening Siege by Syrian Rebels Stirs Anger
item.description: Syrian rebels tighten a siege on government-held areas of Aleppo to get civilians to go elsewhere, but it seems to be undermining support for their cause.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Aleppo residents returned from shopping for Ramadan on Wednesday along a passageway separating government and rebel-held areas.

item.title: Japanese Nuclear Plant May Have Been Leaking for Two Years
item.description: The finding brings into sharp relief the precariousness of the cleanup at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, where three of the six reactors suffered core meltdowns.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Journalist Was Killed by Army Sniper He Filmed, Family Says
item.description: The family of a photographer for an Islamist newspaper who was killed on Monday, moments after recording an image of a sniper aiming a rifle at him, told The Lede that legal action is planned against the soldier.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: An image posted online by the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party of Ahmed Assem, 26, a photographer for the Islamist movement's newspaper who was killed on Monday.

item.title: China and Russia, in a Display of Unity, Hold Naval Exercises
item.description: The Obama administration sending more military power to Asia in part led to China seeking stronger military and economic relations with Russia, a country it has long regarded with suspicion.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Chinese sailors mooring the destroyer Shenyang last week upon their arrival in Vladivostok for joint drills with Russia.

item.title: Moscow Journal : Russian Circuses Offer Tigers and Bears as Props
item.description: In Russia, land of the risk taker, circuses routinely allow children to have their picture taken with dangerous animals.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Former South Korean Spy Chief Charged With Bribery
item.description: Won Sei-hoon, who served as director of the National Intelligence Service, is the latest in a series of former spy chiefs who have faced criminal indictments after leaving office.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bombing Kills Top Security Aide to Pakistan President
item.description: President Asif Ali Zardari’s Pakistan Peoples Party portrayed the attack in Karachi as a warning to the president.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Berlusconi's Party Stops Parliament
item.description: Almost all activity was halted in both houses of Parliament in Italy after a court hearing was set for the former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Luxembourg Spying Scandal Breaks Juncker Government
item.description: Luxembourg's Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker on Wednesday bowed to pressure for an early election after his junior coalition partner blamed him for failing to curb abuses of power by the secret service.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Retailers Offer Safety Plan for Bangladeshi Factories
item.description: Wal-Mart, Gap, Target, Kohl’s, Macy’s and a dozen other retailers are unveiling their alternative to a European-led plan to improve safety at apparel factories in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and STEPHANIE CLIFFORD
item.media:description: Bangladeshi garment workers called for better working conditions at a rally in Dhaka on Sunday.

item.title: Czech Leader Swears in Interim Government
item.description: President Milos Zeman’s confirmation of a leftist loyalist as prime minister was done in open defiance of the main parties in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic arrived at a swearing-in ceremony for an interim government on Wednesday in Prague.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 10
item.description: The Jagannath Rath Yatra in Kolkata, West Bengal.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A priest sitting near the idol of Lord Jagannath during the annual Jagannath Rath Yatra festival in Kolkata, West Bengal.

item.title: Drones in Niger Reflect New U.S. Tack on Terrorism
item.description: A drone base established in February to track militants in Mali is the latest indication of the priority Africa has become for the United States, but the strategy has limitations.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: India Ink: Remains of the Day in Kokrajhar
item.description: A series of award-winning photographs chronicle the ethnic violence that broke out in the Kokrajhar district of Assam in the summer of 2012.
item.dc:creator: By VIVEK SINGH

item.title: Greek Unions Call Strike to Protest Cuts
item.description: The country’s two largest unions called a general strike for Tuesday to protest the latest round of austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Egypt Is Arena for Influence of Arab Rivals
item.description: Three of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies have pledged $12 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: The interim Egyptian president, Adli Mansour, center, met with officials of the United Arab Emirates in Cairo on Tuesday.
